metadata.titleEn: 3-D thermal regime and petrologic metamorphism in Sumatra (2001-2010)
metadata.description: The data includes the three-dimensional temperature field (degrees Celsius), water content (wt%), dehydration rate (wt%/km), rock phase change distribution, and subduction velocity field (cm/yr) of the subducting plate, as well as the coastline and volcano distribution in southern and southwestern Alaska. The data coordinates are temporarily an orthogonal coordinate system, where the origin of the coordinates is (98.10E, 2.40S), the x+ azimuth is 230 degrees clockwise from the north, the y+ azimuth is 140 degrees clockwise from the north, and the z+ direction is vertical downwards, in kilometers. The data source method is a three-dimensional finite-difference numerical simulation. The geophysical calculation is ensured after the subduction thermal regime reaches a steady state. The temperature field error range is ±10 degrees Celsius, and the velocity field error range is ±0.1cm/ yr. This data can be used to further analyze the geophysical field of the subduction zone.

background: The Sumatra convergent plate boundary accommodates noticeable oblique convergence between the Sunda and Indian-Australian plates. The oblique subduction associated strike-slip motion in the Sumatra-Andaman sector has contributed to the formation of a seismically fragile sliver plate between the subduction margin and a complex fault system. According to the United States Geological Survey, at least 40 great earthquakes have damaged coastal Sumatra, including Mw7.9 (Enggano, 2000 June), Mw9.1 (Sumatra-Andaman, 2004 December), Mw8.6 (Nias-Simeulue, 2005 March), Mw8.4 (2007 September), Mw7.9 (2007 September), and Mw7.8 (Banyak, 2010 April) earthquakes. The 1833 earthquake has been estimated to be Mw9.0 using records of uplift taken from coral microatolls. Most of these giant earthquakes are associated with devastating tsunamis. Over the past half century, the major convergent strains in the area were released, according to the vertical level of the microatolls. The large thrust off of the shore of coastal Sumatra is predominantly less than 40 km deep, and it slipped more than 20 m in the 2004 Mw9.1 earthquake. Coral microatoll records also reveal a 15-year-long reversal of interseismic vertical displacement from subsidence to uplift between 1966 and 1981, which reflects 15-year-long slow-slip events (SSEs) on the Sunda megathrust near Banyak Island, with multidecade geodetic records showing the full spectrum of slip behavior. Tectonic tremors are also found in close association with geodetically observed SSE occurrence on the Banyak Islands of North Sumatra, as revealed by coral observations.
research objective: In this study, we focus on fast and slow earthquakes and their thermohydrous states in the Sumatran tectonic complex based on 3-D numerical simulation. The joint effects of metamorphized rocks of the incoming plate on the generation of fast and slow earthquakes beneath Sumatra are also investigated.
methods: By combining the updated geometry of the incoming plate through seismic tomography (Slab 2.0, Hayes et al., 2018) and using surface heat flow observations (Pollack et al., 1993) and the estimate from the Curie point depth (Li et al., 2017) as constraints, we constructed a 3-D thermomechanical model developed from code Stag3D (Tackley & Xie, 2003) to predict the Sumatran thermal and hydrous states to better understand the Sunda megathrust subduction thermodynamics. The model evolves over time simultaneously with plate subduction and specifically computes temperature variation, water content, and slab dehydration; then, the model results are compared with earthquake distribution. We performed sensitivity tests to investigate the robustness of our modeling results and varied the mantle viscosity from 0.9 × 10^20 to 1.1 × 10^20 Pa s, and mantle density from 3,250 to 3,350 kg/m^3.
findings: The temperature of earthquake-stricken Sumatra megathrust varies from 200°C to 500°C in a cross-arc width of approximately 50–150 km determined by a changing dip angle. Slab dehydration of the water-rich MORB and ultramafic rocks in the oceanic lithosphere beneath Sumatra releases a large amount of fluid into the continental wedge. The fluids derived from slab dehydration are prone to upwelling following the subduction channel along the plate interface and thus contribute to the large earthquakes clustered directly updip of the dehydration front, posing an abundant fluid interface and high seismic risk beneath offshore Sumatra. The dehydration front in the subducted upper lithosphere at a depth of approximately 30–60 km produces fast and slow earthquakes, while the subducted lower lithosphere at a depth of approximately 80–120 km influences arc magmatism.

Definition.Question: What is a 3-D finite difference numerical simulation in the context of geophysical data collection?
Definition.Answer: A 3-D finite difference numerical simulation is a computational approach used to model complex physical phenomena, such as the temperature field and rock phase changes in a subduction zone. It involves discretizing the physical space into a grid and solving the equations governing the physical processes at each grid point over time. This method enables researchers to predict and analyze the geophysical characteristics of regions like the Sumatra subduction zone, providing insights into temperature variation, water content, and slab dehydration.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of using 3-D finite difference numerical simulation to generate a temperature field compare to using seismic tomography for understanding subduction zone thermodynamics?
Comparison.Answer: The 3-D finite difference numerical simulation provides a direct calculation of the temperature field, taking into account the thermohydrous state over time, whereas seismic tomography offers a geometrical update of the incoming plate, which can serve as a constraint for models predicting temperature variations. Both methods complement each other, with tomography providing structural insights and numerical simulations offering dynamic thermal and hydrous state predictions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the occurrence of both fast and slow earthquakes in the Sumatran tectonic complex?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The occurrence of both fast and slow earthquakes in the Sumatran tectonic complex is influenced by the thermal and hydrous states of the area, slab dehydration processes, and the fluid dynamics along the plate interface. The distribution of fluids and the dehydration front's position relative to the subduction zone play significant roles in earthquake generation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating 3-D numerical simulation results with seismic tomography on our understanding of earthquake dynamics in subduction zones?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating 3-D numerical simulation results with seismic tomography can enhance our understanding of earthquake dynamics by providing a detailed model of the thermal and hydrous states. This can reveal how temperature variations and slab dehydration affect earthquake generation, potentially uncovering the role of fluids in the seismic risk beneath offshore Sumatra.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications of varying mantle viscosity and density in sensitivity tests for understanding the robustness of subduction models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Varying mantle viscosity and density in sensitivity tests allows researchers to evaluate the robustness of subduction models by examining how these parameters influence temperature and fluid distribution. Such tests can help determine the stability of model predictions and identify critical factors affecting earthquake and magmatic processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use 3-D numerical simulation when investigating the thermohydrous states of tectonic complexes like the Sumatran subduction zone?
Goal Orientation.Answer: 3-D numerical simulation is crucial to accurately model and understand the thermal and hydrous states of the Sumatran tectonic complex, as it allows for the detailed prediction of temperature variations, water content, and slab dehydration processes that are integral to understanding the subduction thermodynamics and their role in earthquake generation.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to perform sensitivity tests by varying mantle viscosity and density in the development of a thermomechanical model for the Sumatran subduction zone?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Performing sensitivity tests by varying mantle viscosity and density is necessary to assess the robustness and reliability of the thermomechanical model, ensuring that the predictions remain consistent under different geophysical conditions and providing a comprehensive understanding of the factors influencing the thermodynamics of the subduction process.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural methods are employed to construct a 3-D temperature field model for subduction zones, and how do they ensure accuracy in temperature prediction?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To construct a 3-D temperature field model for subduction zones, seismic tomography is used for updating the geometry of the incoming plate, and constraints from surface heat flow observations and estimates from the Curie point depth are applied. The model is developed using the Stag3D code to predict the thermal and hydrous states, with sensitivity tests conducted to ensure robustness and accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the accurate simulation of three-dimensional temperature fields and phase transitions in subduction zones?
Enablement.Answer: The use of three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulation methods enables the accurate simulation of temperature fields and phase transitions in subduction zones, with the model evolving over time simultaneously with plate subduction and computing temperature variation, water content, and slab dehydration.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of seismic tomography and surface heat flow observations enable a comprehensive understanding of subduction zone dynamics?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of seismic tomography and surface heat flow observations provides constraints that enable the construction of a detailed 3-D thermomechanical model, helping to predict the thermal and hydrous states in subduction zones and understand subduction thermodynamics.

Enablement.Question: What factors contribute to the enhanced accuracy of predicting earthquake distribution in subduction zones through numerical simulations?
Enablement.Answer: Factors contributing to enhanced accuracy include the updated geometry of the incoming plate from seismic tomography, the constraints from surface heat flow observations, and sensitivity tests performed by varying mantle viscosity and density, which help in comparing model results with earthquake distributions.

Expectation.Question: What expectations could lead researchers to focus on the dehydration processes in subducting plates when studying earthquake generation beneath Sumatra?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers may expect that dehydration processes play a critical role in earthquake generation due to the release of fluids from subducted oceanic lithosphere, which can affect seismicity by influencing the mechanical properties of the subduction interface and contributing to fluid upwelling. This expectation is grounded in the understanding that fluid presence is a significant factor in seismic risk assessment.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using 3-D finite difference numerical simulation as a data collection method for understanding the Sumatra subduction zone thermodynamics?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of 3-D finite difference numerical simulation is effective for understanding the Sumatra subduction zone thermodynamics as it allows for detailed modeling of temperature variations, water content, and slab dehydration in a complex geological setting. This method provides a comprehensive approach to simulate the physical conditions at depth, offering insights that can be correlated with earthquake distribution and other geophysical phenomena.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore possible methodologies for collecting three-dimensional temperature field data and rock phase transition distribution in a subduction zone.
Request/Directive.Answer: The three-dimensional temperature field and rock phase transition distribution in a subduction zone can be collected using three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulations. This method involves simulating the subduction process until it reaches a steady state and calculating the physical parameters, such as temperature, water content, and dehydration rates. These simulations require constraints from seismic tomography, surface heat flow observations, and estimates from Curie point depth to build accurate models.
